title: French I
requirements: Not for students who have taken FREN2000,2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
description: As the first in a series of six language courses, this course invites students without prior knowledge of French to explore the basic features of the French language. Supported by audiovisual aids, students will receive intensive practice in spoken and written French through interactive class work, homework and online exercises. They will become familiar with the basic concepts of French grammar and learn how to interact in some simple everyday situations.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1) master the basic communication skills such as greeting somebody (2) exchanging basic personal information with someone in a social gathering (3) describing an object or a person, shopping.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the following 7 lessons of the textbook Le nouveau Taxi 1: lessons 1 – 7   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 1 Bienvenue! (Welcome!) - Greeting (1) - Introducing oneself - Inquiring / Giving information: name & nationality - Conjugation: - être / - s’appeler - Subject pronouns’ gender:   masculine vs feminine (il vs. elle)  - The question word qui - Elision   Leçon 2 Qui est-ce ? (Who is it?) - Introducing someone:  - first name , family name - profession - address: city & country   - Noun group (1):  - definite article + noun  - Noun’s gender: masculine vs. feminine - Adjective’s agreement: in gender & number - preposition + country/city   Leçon 3 Ça va bien? (How are you?) - Giving information about a person: - name, age, profession, address & phone number - greetings (2) - asking / giving / understanding basic personal information - Numbers 21 - 69 - Irregular Verbs: aller, avoir - Possessive adjectives (1) - Indefinite articles - Interrogative adjectives (1)   Leçon 4 Correspond@nce (Correspondence) - Revision: lessons 1 - 3. Talk about taste and preferences - “La francophonie” (French speaking countries)     Leçon 5 Trouvez l’objet (Find the object) - Describing a room and its objects - Indicating the location of an object - Locating an object - Prepositions & prepositional phrases of place - Adverbs of place - Definite & Indefinite articles (2) - The French idiom: Il y a … - Sentence structure with Qu’est-ce que …   Leçon 6 Portrait-robot (Photofit) - Describing people & objects - Colors - Talking about color - Stressed pronouns (1) - The verb avoir - The negative particles ne … pas - Adjectives’ agreement (with noun or pronoun) - Possessive Adjectives (2)   Leçon 7  Shopping - Describing objects (2) - Asking price - Describing an object - Clothes shopping - Filling an order-form - Numbers : 70 - 1000 - Question word: comment, combien - Interrogative adjectives (2) - Demonstrative adjectives
required_readings: •  Textbook: Méthode de français Le nouveau Taxi 1, Ed. Hachette, Français Langue étrangère. •  Exercises book: Cahier d’exercices Le nouveau Taxi 1. Information about how to get the textbook will be given in the first lesson.  E-learning platform: https://moodle.cuhk.edu.hk
recommended_readings: Recommended materials: • A desk-size bilingual dictionary, such as Robert & Collins senior or Larousse   (pocket-size dictionaries are not recommended). • Please see the list of websites available in the platform https://moodle.cuhk.edu.hk

title: Invitation to French Online
requirements:
Not for students who have taken FREN1000, 2000, 2001, 2050, 3000, 3001, 3002, 3050 or 3051
From 2023-24, students can only earn up to 2 units of these courses: CLCP1001,CLCP1101,CLCC1001,CLCC1101,JASP1350,HKSL1001,SPAN1001,GERM1001,KORE1001,FREN1001
description: [This course is offered via asynchronous online mode. Students should register the course via KEEP, a CUHK eLearning platform where the course materials are uploaded.]This course is for students without prior knowledge of French to discover some aspects of the French culture along with some basic elements of the French language. With the support of audio-visual materials, short textual information, different interactive tasks and online tests, it aims to help students get familiar with practical and cultural aspects of daily life in a French-speaking environment. It serves as a taster for students who might consider taking three-unit or six-unit French courses offered by the French programme of CUHK in the future.
outcome: Upon completion of the course, students are expected to be able to: - understand some basic features of the French language.  - interact in simple French in daily contexts, e.g., greetings, ordering food in a restaurant, expressing preferences for the food, etc. - learn French independently as part of their learning experience.
syllabus: Language Components Culture Components   Unit 1: Bienvenue à la résidence  (Welcome to the residence) - Formal and informal expressions for greeting and closing conversations: Bonjour/ Salut/ Enchanté(e)/ Au revoir… (Hello/ Hi/ Nice to meet you/ Good bye…). - Being polite: S’il vous plaît/ Excusez-moi/ Merci/ Bienvenue. (Please/ Excuse me/ Thank you/ Welcome).  - Formal and informal introductions: Comment vous vous appelez/ Comment tu t’appelles ?/ Et toi ?/ Tu viens d’où ? Etc. (What is your name?/ And you?/ Where do you come from? etc.). - Grammar: verbs S’appeler/ Être (To call oneself/ To be)- Vocabulary: occupations. Meeting people:  - Formal vs informal situations.    Unit 2:  Bon appétit!  (Enjoy your meal!)   - Ordering food and the drink in a restaurant:    - Je voudrais … s’il vous plaît (I would like to have …please) - Pour moi, … s’il vous plaît (For me, … please)  Un thé / un café/une limonade / une bière / … (a (cup of) tea/ a (cup of) coffee/ a (glass of) lemonade/ a (glass of) beer/…) - Starting the meal:    Bon appétit! (Enjoy your meal!) -Saying “Cheers” in French:   Santé / À votre santé ! (Cheers!) - Asking the bill: - L’addition, s’il vous plaît! (The bill, please) - Expressing appreciation on food: C’est délicieux ! / c’est bon ! (It’s delicious!/ It’s good) French-style meal:   - Hors d'œuvre (starter), main course, drinks and wine, cheese, dessert.   Unit 3:   On sort! (Let’s go out!) - Suggesting and choosing a place for cultural exposure:  Un film ? Ça te dit ? (How about watching a movie?) Ou un musée ? (Or visiting a museum?) - Expressing appreciation: C’est beau!/ C’est magnifique. (It’s beautiful/ It’s wonderful) J’aime beaucoup/Je préfère. (I like it very much/ I prefer) - Agreeing/disagreeing with the suggestion: D’accord!/ J’adore la sculpture !   (Okay!/ I love sculpture)- Oh là là, non, je déteste le rap ! (Oh dear, no, I hate hip hop!) Introduction of two  monuments and two museums of Paris:   - La tour Eiffel. - L’Arc de Triomphe. - Le Louvre. - Le musée Guimet.   Unit 4:  Au cinéma(At the movies) - Choosing a movie: On va au cinéma?/ Quel film ?/... (Let’s go to the movies?/  What film?/ ...)   - Expressing simple attitudes and opinions: disappointment, excitement, boredom… Zut/ Quel dommage/ J’aime…/ Je n’aime pas…/ C’est super/ C’est nul… (Shoot/ What a pity/ I like…/ I don’t like…/ It’s great/ It sucks…)- Asking “how are you?” Comment ça va?/ Super bien/ Ça va… (How are you?/ Great/ I am OK…)- Introducing someone: Je te présente Stéphanie/ C’est qui ?... (This is Stéphanie/ Who is it?...)- Vocabulary: movie genres and adjectives to express positive and negative opinions. Une comédie/ Un film d’action… (A comedy/ An action movie…) Super/ Nul/Ennuyeux/ Belle…(Great/ Bad/ Boring/ Beautiful…) Manners in public places: - Speaking on the phone in a public place.- Interacting with a staff and strangers in a cinema.   Unit 5:  Le club de sport  (The sports club)  - Requesting information at a sports club: Bonjour, c’est pour une inscription, s’il vous plaît. (Hello, it is for registration, please.)  C’est pour le foot. (It is for soccer) Je voudrais des informations. (I would like some information)  C’est combien ? (How much is it?)   -Understanding some information given at a sports club: C’est gratuit pour les étudiants. (It is free for students.)   -Understanding some questions frequently asked at a sports club: - C’est pour le tennis? (It is for tennis?) - Vous avez une photo ? C’est pour la carte de membre. (Do you have a photograph? It is for the membership card) - Vous avez une carte d’étudiant ? (Do you have a student card?)   -Understanding some instruction given at a sports club: -Complétez ce formulaire, s’il vous plait. (Fill in this form, please.)-Inscrivez votre nom, votre prénom et votre adresse. (Write down your name, your first name and your address.) Sports activities in France:  le tennis, le foot and some other major types of sports in France.   Manners in formal situation: -Handing politely a document.-Expressing agreement.   Unit 6 :  Bonnes fêtes !  (Happy Holidays!)  -Introducing a person to a friend and thanking for an invitation: Voici un ami. (Here is a friend.) ; Je te présente. (I introduce (her/him) to you.);  Enchanté (Nice to meet you) Merci pour l’invitation ! (Thanks for the invitation!); Avec plaisir ! (With pleasure!)  - Asking questions about a holiday: C’est comment, le Nouvel an en France ? (How is New Year’s Day like in France?); Et les activités ? (And what about the activities?); Et demain soir, tu vas où ? (And tomorrow night, where do you go?); La Saint-Valentin, en France, c’est quand ? (Valentine’s Day, in France, when is it?); Avec qui? (With whom?) Et on fait quoi? (And what do we do?)   -Talking about what people do in general (during a holiday):On mange (We eat); on danse (we dance); on boit (we drink); on s’embrasse (we kiss each other); on va dans un bar (we go in a bar), on sort au restaurant pour un dîner en amoureux (we go out for a romantic dinner), etc. Introduction of the New Year celebrations in France: the customs, the activities, the food and drinks and the greetings used during that event.    Introduction of the celebration of Valentine’s Day: the date, the activities, the expression frequently used and the gifts frequently offered.

title: Made in France

outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to be able to: (1) Analyze the main cultural traits of French. (2) Globally understand the culture of contemporary France and to take a critical look on it.

title: French II
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN2001,2050,3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
2. Prerequisite: FREN1000
description: Building on the knowledge acquired in FREN1000, this course aims to further develop students’ ability to communicate in French in various everyday situations. It also seeks to give students a taste of French culture and invites them to explore cultural differences. Through intensive practice students will develop more confidence in interacting in French while further expanding and solidifying their understanding of the basic grammar and pronunciation patterns.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1) master the basic communication skills such as asking for direction or ordering food at a restaurant (2) be able to traveling in a French speaking country, buying train or airplane tickets  (3) talking about one’s daily activities and habits, relating past events.
syllabus: Course syllabus: The course will cover the following 8 lessons of the textbook Le Nouveau TAXI 1: lessons 10, 11, 13, 14, 15, 17, 18, 19.   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 10: Pour aller au Louvre? (How to go to the Louvre ?) - Asking the way: Direction & means of transportation. - Sentence structure: The imperative mood. - Prepositions: - the contracted forms au , du - à & en + means of transportation. - Adverb of place: y   Leçon 11: Voyages, voyages (Travel, travel) - Situating a place on a map. - Giving advice. - Expression: - C’est + Noun Group - C’est + Adjective - C’est + Adverbial of place - The Subject pronoun on. - Prepositions of place.   Leçon 13: Vous partez quand ? (When are you leaving? ) - Hours & Dates - Polite questions. - Question with - Quand … ? - Quelle heure est-il ? - Verb : partir (present tense)   Leçon 14: À Genève (At Geneva) - Jobs and Professions. - Asking for information. - Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.- Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.- Verb: faire (present tense) - Question structure with est-ce que - Gender of Noun.   Leçon 15: Le dimanche matin (Sunday morning) - What one is doing. - What one is used to do. - Sports. - Verbs: lire, écrire (present tense) - Verbes pronominaux (Part I) - Le dimanche / dimanche prochain.   Leçon 17: Mardi gras - Expressions of need. - Talking about habitude. - Expressions of quantity - Partitive articles: du, de la, de l’ - Verbs: - boire, acheter & manger (present tense)   Leçon 18: Une bonne journée (A good day)            - Talking about past events (I) - Giving personal opinion. - Paying compliments. - The tense Passé composé (I) with auxiliary verb avoir. - Basic forms of the past participle in French. - Agreement of Adjective : beau   Leçon 19 : Où sont-ils allés ? (Where have they been ?) - Talking about past events (II) - Expressions of duration. - The tense Passé composé (II) with auxiliary verb être. - Markers of time.

title: French III
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
2. Prerequisite: FREN2000 or FREN2050
description: This course aims to further enhance students’ communication skills in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Students are expected to communicate confidently in a wider range of social interactions including more formal situations and simple professional contexts as well as reporting past events and sharing experience. At the end of this course, students will have completed a proficiency level comparable to level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference for Languages (CEFR).
outcome: After taking this course, the student is expected to be able to express his/her opinion about simple issues or to express objections, to give advice or to make suggestions. He/she would know how to behave and interact in a situation related to work such as looking for a job, asking for information about a job advertisement, attending a job interview, speaking with colleagues, etc. On the other hand, the student should be capable to speak about holidays, activities during days off and leisure time.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the following 6 lessons of the textbook Le nouveau TAXI 1: lessons 21 – 27   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 21 C’est interdit! (It is prohibited!) - Asking for permission: - Accepting / Refusing - Expressions of prohibition - Verb: pouvoir + verb 2 - The indirect object pronouns - Imperative + Negative   Leçon 22 Petites annonces. (Classified.) - Talking about capability & will - Talking about obligation - Verbs: vouloir, savoir - The impersonal verb: falloir : Il faut - Expressing future events : futur proche   Leçon 23 Qu’est-ce qu’on lui offre? (What should we give her?) - Making suggestions : - Accepting / Refusing - Verbs: connaître - Direct object pronouns. - Indirect object pronouns.   Leçon 25 Enquête. (Report.)  -Expressing likes & dislikes - Expressing frequency - Expressing intensity - Pronouns: en, ça - The negative form: ne … plus    Leçon 26 Quitter Paris. (Leaving Paris.) - Expressing opinions - Expressing objections - The question word:   pourquoi - The conjunctive phrase: parce que / parce qu’… - Adv. of intensity + Adj.: assez / trop + adjective - Expression of quantity + Noun : assez de / trop de + Noun  - Adj.: Tout / toute / tous / tous - Pronouns: tous / toutes    Leçon 27  Vivement les vacances! (Can’t wait for holiday!) - Expressing appreciation / depreciation - Giving advice - Verbes pronominaux: *se lever. *position of the reflexive pronoun in imperative mood

title: Sounds of French
description: This course is an introduction to the phonetic system of the French language. Illustrations and examples will be taken from modern spoken French. Similarities and differences to other languages will also be examined when appropriate. Students learning French are encouraged to take this course.
outcome: After taking this course, students are expected to: (1)be able to use the International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA) and the IPA symbols provided in dictionaries; (2)understand, compare and hypothesize on the production of speech sounds (place of articulation, differences and common points…); (3)understand and describe the rhythmic groups and intonation patterns of modern French; (4)be able to pronounce/read out modern French and analyze phenomenon of spoken French; (5)be able to play with words sonority and create short rhymes/ poems/ songs…
syllabus: • Types of Speech sound in modern French (International Phonetic Alphabet (IPA)): - Vowel,  - Consonant,  - Semi-vowel, - Phonemes, - Distinctive features and minimal pair.   • French Syllable: - Syllable structures (open syllable/close syllable), - Syllabification and syllable boundary, - Vowel clusters/Consonant clusters, - Final letter: final consonant; final /e/ (Schwa [ә]).   • French Syllable & Rhythmic groups: - Pronunciation of numbers, - Enchaînement, - Liaison: obligatoire, interdite, facultative, - Elision, - [ә] caduc.   • Intonation patterns: - Pitch, - Stress, - Duration.   • If time allows: - Expressive intonation patterns, - Usual foreign words.  All through the term, spoken and written French will be used (dialogues, rhymes, poem, prose…).

title: French IV
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN3001,3002,3050 or 3051
2. Prerequisite: FREN2001
description: This course aims at increasing students’ communicative fluency in oral and written French. Using a variety of classroom activities and multimedia, students will build up their competence in the four language domains listening, speaking, reading and writing. Through intensive practice they will be able to communicate in a wide range of social situations with the appropriate awareness of the pragmatic rules involved. Students receive guidance in the process of composing longer texts displaying a range of registers and styles relating to past, present and future events.
outcome: The student should be able to tell about his/her childhood and any other story in the past tense. Moreover, he/she will be expected to be able to understand an event mentioned in a newspaper or on the radio and to report it again. In the end, he/she should be capable to make plans, to propose conditions and to express intention and certitude as well as eventuality.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the following 6 lessons of the textbook TAXI 2: lessons 11,14,19,21,25,27   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 29 Enfant de la ville(City Child) - Talking about a recent events - Talking about events and habits in the past - Passé récent : venir de + inf. - Form of the imparfait tense   Leçon 30 Fait divers(News in Brief) - Talking about events and states of mind in the past. - Describing circumstances.. - Form and use of passé composé and imparfait - Differences about the two tenses.   Leçon 31 Ma première histoire d’amour(My First Love Story) - Locating events in the time. - Expressing purposes : Goals & objectives. - Dates, moment and duration. - The use of the preposition pour + inf. - Past participles.   Leçon 32 La 2CV… et autres symboles.(2CV car… and other symbols)  Revision    Leçon 33 Beau Fixe(Nice Weather) - Talking about weather. - Expressing eventuality & certitude. - Tense : Le futur (simple)   Leçon 34 Projets d’avenir(Projects about the Future) - Making projects. - Locating events in the time. - Tenses for denoting future events : présent , futur proche , futur simple - Adverbs & adverbial phrases of time for future events.   Leçon 35  Envie de changement(Willing to Change) - Making conditions. - Expressing one’s intention. - Hypothesis & condition with si - quand + future tense. - Other irregular verbs in future tense.   Leçon 36 Le pain, mangez-en !(Eat Bread!)   Revision

title: French V
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN3002 or 3051
2. Prerequisite: FREN3000 or 3050
description: This course focuses on the further development of communication skills in French with emphasis on the expression of personal views and the training of argumentative strategies. The course will also engage students in critical reflections on various aspects of life in French-speaking countries and their own social environment. Students will be guided to analyze various types of data to support their views. They will learn how to express their wishes and aspirations using the appropriate registers.
outcome: After taking this course, the student is expected to be able to :  • Talk about their life, their tastes, share their experiences.  • Make projects and talk about their objectives.  • Describe and compare their living environment. • Explain problems and issues, give advice, suggest solutions and make hypothesis.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the following 5 lessons of the textbook Echo 2 lessons 1,2,4,6,7.   Lesson Speech acts Grammar   Leçon 1 Vivement demain ! (Can’t wait for tomorrow!)  - Make projects and suggestions. - express concerns and reassure people. - make comparisons . - Revision of tense: future. - Comparative. - Superlative.   Leçon 2 Tu as du boulot ? (Do you have a job ?) - Express one’s taste and preference. - Make suppositions.  -Pronoun : en. -Pronoun : y. -Expressions of condition. Negative questions + si / non.   Leçon 4 C’est tout un programme ! (Such a programm !) - Choose a TV programm and give opinion. - Give instructions. - Welcome someone. - Relative pronouns : qui/que/où. - Adverbes. - « en + participe présent ».   + if time allows : Revision and Extras.   Leçon 6 C’est la fête ! (Let’s party !) - Express one’s taste. - Talk about parties and festivals. - Meet again - Approach someone. - Revision COI/COD. - Agreement of past participle.   Leçon 7 Vous plaisantez ! (Are you kidding ?) - Formulate hypotheses. -Suggest something and react to a suggestion. - Talk about movements. -Tense: Conditionnal Present. -Conditionnal Present/ Si+imparfait.   + if time allows : Revision and Extras.

title: French VI
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN3051 
2. Prerequisite: FREN3001
description: This course builds on the knowledge acquired through previous French language courses. It aims at leading students to a proficiency level comparable to the threshold from A2 to B1 of the Common European Framework for Languages (CEFR), becoming “independent users” of French. To achieve this goal, students will be encouraged to work project-based through independent or collaborative work with their peers. At the end of this course students will have mastered the most important grammar features of French and be able to communicate effectively in a wide range of everyday situations and a number of professional contexts. They will be able to use their oral and written language skills to relate to, reflect on and analyze past and current issues involving the French-speaking societies.
outcome: Students will learn how to :  • gives advises and suggestions.  • express opinions and feelings.  • talk about leisure activities and justify the choice. • talk about a trip and past experience.
syllabus: Course Content: The course will cover the following 6 lessons of the textbook TAXI 2: lessons 11,14,19,21,25,27    Lesson   Speech acts   Grammar    Leçon 11 Demain, j’arrête … (tomorrow I stop) - Talking about goals - Giving advise, suggesting solutions  - Devoir + V. infinitif -Tense: subjonctive   Leçon 27 Questions de valeur (questions of values)  - expressing and qualifying one’s feelings  - revision of the subjonctive present - expressions using subjunctive and infinitive   Leçon 14 A mi-temps (Half time) - Expressing a restriction - Adverb using <ment> - Negation ( lesson 17)   Leçon 19 Destination week-end ( destination for weekend)  - Talking about one’s leisure  activities  - Gerund -expressions of chronological difference between 2 actions ( lesson 30) -en train de + V.infinitif   Leçon 21 Heureux, qui comme Ulysse… (happy like Ulysse) - telling a story using past tense - talking about a trip, past experience… - passé compose (revision) - passé compose “avoir”: ageement of the past participle   Leçon 25 Réussir sa vie (succeed one’s life) - report a speech, questions, and answers - taking stock of one s life  - indirect speech / present tense

title: French Conversation
description: This course aims to enhance students’ oral communication skills in French. Through selected student-oriented stimuli and topics related to social issues and contemporary affairs, students will practice the expression and exchange of personal views and ideas. Classroom activities may include in-class activities such as dialogue, role-play, narration, speech, group discussion, debate and multimedia activities. Emphasis will be placed on oral practice and an interactive learning environment with a view to helping students build confidence and develop fluency in using the language, to speak spontaneously in social interaction and acquire conversational techniques commonly used in a French-speaking environment.

title: French Reading and Creative Writing
description: This course is designed for students who study French and want to enhance their reading and writing skills through literary texts and excerpts. The emphasis will be placed on the reading of French texts and poems which lead to creative writings in French. The objective of the course is to equip students with language keys to comprehend the texts and subsequently produce creative texts in French. All texts are in French.

title: Business French I
description: This course is designed to introduce and train in active practice in a wide range of business related dialogues, as well as to acquire the basic skills of business terminology through the reading of short commercial documents.

title: French III & IV

description: This is a summer intensive French language course, covering the full syllabus of FREN2001 and 3000.

title: French V & VI
requirements:
1. Not for students who have taken FREN3001 or FREN3002
2. Prerequisite: FREN3000 or FREN3050
description: This is a summer intensive French language course, covering the full syllabus of FREN3001 and 3002.

title: French through Short Films
requirements:
Prerequisite: FREN3000,3001,3002,3050 or 3051
Not for students who have taken FREN3100 in 2nd term 2019-20
description: This course aims to strengthen and expand students’ language skills like speaking, listening, writing and reading. This will allow students to have better understanding of French culture and current French societal tendency. It places special emphasis on conversational fluency, grammatical accuracy and vocabulary acquisition. The course is mainly designed from several awarded shorts films and one movie. TV commercials and short videos will be used as supplementary materials. These pedagogical resources will provide the basis for interactive class activities that will help students to develop their language skills and to build language confidence. The course also aims to enhance students’ critical analysis on popular beliefs like clichés about France.

title: Special Topics in French
description: This course aims at furthering students' understanding of selected area(s) of French language, literature or culture. Topics will vary from year to year. Offerings with different subtitles can be taken up for credit, up to a maximum of two times.

title: French Through Literature
requirements:
Pre-requisite(s): FREN3000,3050,3001,3002,3051 or equivalent competence
Not for students who have taken FREN3100 in 2016-17
description: This course aims at enhancing the student’s command in reading and writing of French through the study of French literary works. Through activities such as creative writing, drama performance, role-playing and group discussion, students will familiarize themselves with different literary forms (poems, novels, plays, etc.) in French. The course also aims at enriching student’s general knowledge about French literary culture and allowing them to explore the writings of selected famous French authors in the specific context of their historical/biographical and cultural background. Students will be exposed to selected works through multimedia such as movies, voice recordings, songs and visual illustrations.
outcome: At the completion of this course the students will be able to : • Write in French in a creative and more elaborative way to express their ideas. • Have a better reading ability in French. • Recognize the main elements of literary genres such as poetry, novel and plays and assess their significance. • Place authors and literary text in their cultural and historical context and be able to analyze texts from different genres. • Students will be able to comprehend and respond with an enhanced command of French in reading and writing and a heightened cultural awareness.
syllabus: Unit  Objectives  Themes  Culture   Unit I La Poésie pour parler de soi.(Introducing oneself in a form of poetry) -Introducing and writing about oneself through diverse poetical forms. -Exploring and getting familiar with a variety of forms of poems. -Writing by imitating or by following precise instructions. -Having some knowledge about History of poetry and some major French poets. -Developping a personal understanding of some selected major French Poems. -Classifying poetry in historical context. -Likes and dislikes. -Hobbies. -Childhood and adulthood. -Family. -Wishes and hopes. -Time.   -20th century Surrealism. -Calligraphy in poetry. -Popular and famous poems and poets of the XIX and XXth century. -Classic poems from Jean de La Fontaine (XVIIe).   Unit IILe Roman pour évoquer la rencontre. (Exploring Novel through scenes of encounter)  -Reading and understanding dialogues. -Writing a narrative text. -Relating past experiences. -Creating characters and write a text about their first encounter. -Accepting, refusing a making proposals. -Defining words. -Expressing feelings. -Love and friendship. -The issue of being different/tolerance. -Childhood. -Family. -XXe Major Novels such as The Little Prince by Saint Exupery or L’Amant by Marguerite Duras. -Discovering Exercises of Styles by Raymond Queneau. -XIXe Romantism (Victor Hugo’s Notre Dame) and Realism (Guy de Maupassant’s short story Simon’s father).   Unit III Le Théâtre : l’interaction et la communication.  (Exploring interaction and communication issue through theater through plays) -Exploring several genre such as comedy and tragedy and the theater of the Absurd.  -Discovering the characteristics and specificity of a theatrical text and its representation on stage.   -Analyzing and performing a passage of a play related to the issue of communication. -By imitation or by following precise instruction, writing a theatrical text and perform it. -Understanding the issue of some scenes taken from various French plays and deepen their understanding. -Comic situation due to misunderstandings. -Education. -Morals and family matters. -XXe Theater of the Absurd : The Lesson by Ionesco, The Misunderstanding by Albert Camus, Waiting for Godot by Samuel Beckett.-XXe Antigone by Jean Anouilh.-XIXe Dindon by George Feydeau.-XVIIe Molière’s The Middle class Gentlemen.
